summary:
Business experience, overview
1988 – 2018     Various technical functions in Shell R&D downstream and upstream.   
-	In downstream, most work was related to combustion/detonation, hydrogen and syngas manufacturing for refineries, gas-to-liquid technology (GTL), cars and domestic use. Focus on experimental developments including issues related to safety.
-	In upstream, most work (reservoir engineering/geomechanics) was related to difficult hydrocarbons (tight gas and ECBM), CO2 sequestration, deep geothermal energy and induced seismicity from hydrocarbon production. Focus on theory and modelling. Advice on various related topics.
-	More or less intensive collaborations with other industrial partners/institutes as UTC, Daimler Benz Ballard, Toshiba, Boskalis, ExxonMobil, EBN, KNMI and TNO. Steering and guidance to university programmes at Imperial College London, University of Utrecht. 
-	Coaching and guiding a substantial number of students (MSc/PhD). Several patents/patent applications and publications.
Main competences
-	Thorough knowledge about fluid flow and rock mechanics. Creative in problem solving. Good engineering and design skills. Able to lead a development team and coaching students, build and sustain relationships with industrial partners and academia.
-       Implementation of multi-physics problems in Finite Element Method software and reasonable
        experience with Python

profile_positions.description:
The work on induced seismicity related to hydrocarbon production included
•	Statistical assessment of the tremor rates and interevent distribution times in the Groningen gas field for NAM. New models based on Weibull distribution of rock failure. Dynamic rupture modelling and analysis of the largest tremors in the field by wave modelling of extended seismic sources. Shell expert proponent in Mmax workshop march 2016. 
Collaborations with ExxonMobil, TNO, Univ. of Utrecht, EBN and KNMI. Presentations to SAC and other stakeholders
profile_positions.title: Principal Research Physicist - Geomechanics and Containment

profile_positions.description:
The work on caprock integrity for CCS  included
•	Caprock integrity around wells in relation to thermo-elastic loading due to the injection of fluids.
•	Clay swelling by dissolved CO2 in brine under high pressures in relation to CCS, and in particular to the integrity of smectite-rich  caprocks. The work included the fundamentals of combining poro-elasticity, thermodynamics of clay swelling and dual porous systems, modelling and guiding experiments.
Dedicated to Goldeneye/Petershead project North Sea. 2 conference presentations, few scientific papers (also for the Dutch  programme related to CCS, CATO).
•	Project steering of the 4 year Shell Grand Challenge Programme with Imperial College, Department of Chemical Engineering (London) on subsurface PVT, subsurface multiphase flow for CCS and ECBM.
•	Guiding the 10 year QCCRSC programme at Imperial College, Department of Chemical Engineering (London) with Shell Qatar and Qatar Petroleum for CCS and guiding CCS related research at the University of Utrecht  (CATO programme) . 
subsurface loop.
•	Industrial representative in the European Mirecol project on issues related to well and caprock integrity for CCS.
profile_positions.title: Principal Research Physicist - Geomechanics and Containment

company.name: SHELL INTERNATIONAL EXPLORATION AND PRODUCTION B.V.

profile_positions.company: SHELL INTERNATIONAL EXPLORATION AND PRODUCTION B.V.
profile_positions.description:
The work on geothermal energy, gas production from tight formations and ECBM, included
•	Technical/economical feasibility study about deep geothermal energy for electricity production.
•	Impairment of gas production in wells in low permeable rock (patent).
•	Coal shrinkage/swelling during an enhanced coal bed methane operation. Development of new theory to couple physical adsorption and poro-elastic response. Participation in and analysis of a CO2 injection experiment in a lignite mine in Slovenia.
•	New well technology concepts to extract underground deposits (patent). This work lead to a Field of Use Agreement and several brainstorming sessions with Boskalis  R&D to reveal fundamental technical showstoppers and best possibilities for further development.  
•	Project steering of the 4 year Shell Grand Challenge Programme with Imperial College, Department of Chemical Engineering (London) on subsurface PVT, subsurface multiphase flow for CCS and ECBM. Guiding the 10 year QCCRSC programme at Imperial College, Department of Chemical Engineering (London) with Shell Qatar and Qatar Petroleum for CCS. Guiding CCS related research at the University of Utrecht  (CATO programme) . 
•	Active member of the technical innovation company Dynamic Dynosaurs (under Shell Technology Ventures) primarily about new well related technology until 2009. Advisor in various Shell Game Changer panels.  Inhouse consultant on geothermal project in US using CO2 as heat exchanger fluid in closed subsurface loop.
profile_positions.title: Principal Research Scientist

profile_positions.description:
The work included
•	Programme leader for residential fuel processor systems for domestic heat and power for the joint venture HydrogenSource  (US based company, 50% Shell Hydrogen, 50% UTCFC (US))  including a collaboration with Toshiba International Fuel Cells (Japan). 
•	Main engineer for the design and development of new fuel processors and other components including mass manufacturing aspects. Design of compact, screw compressor, embedded controller, system safety and safeguarding and the start of a safety certification process (patent).  Selection of a considerable number of manufacturers to deliver fuel processor components.
•	Main engineer for the development of liquid fuel CPO reactors and control for mobile applications in collaboration with Daimler Benz Ballard (patent appl.).
profile_positions.title: Senior engineer – Programme leader in small scale hydrogen production

profile_positions.description:
The work included
•	High-pressure atomisation of heavy oil to scale up of heavy oil residue gasification (SGP) burners (1000 tpd). Design, construction and use of a unique 2M$ high pressure atomisation test facility to study this process.
•	Development of a special optical fibrescope to study flames stabilised on high pressure SGP burners under operation in refineries of Lucky Goldstar (Naju, Korea) and Shell (Pernis, the Netherlands).
•	Development of new burners and syngas cooler fronts for natural gas gasification for gas to liquids (GTL)  (Bintulu, Malaysia), including new experimental tests and the development of a  computer code for radiative heat transfer (patents).
•	Development of new scaling rules for SGP reactors for heavy oil residue gasification.
•	Development of safe and reliable mixers for the catalytic partial oxidation (CPO) process using high pressure pure oxygen and the related development of experimental full scale hazard studies to study accidental ignition of pre-mixed mixtures  (patents).
•	Experimental evaluation of lower olephin production via short-contact time partial oxidation of natural gas.
•	Computational fluid dynamics (CFD) studies using large eddy simulations (LES) with multi-particle interactions to calculate complex heat transfer rates to the SGP burner fronts.
•	Technical advice for Shell Billiton on the design of a flash melting furnace by Otokumpu (Finland) for the treatment of Jarosite waste from zinc production.  Technical advise for Shell France on the development of steam contactors for Kraton production.
profile_positions.title: Engineer / Project leader in Department of Equipment Engineering
